node.title: Tasmanian author tops $80,000 Prime Minister’s Literary Awards, following Miles Franklin win
node.alt: A white woman in her mid 70s with white hair and red scarf and brown winter jacket stands in a green park
node.description: Tasmanian author Amanda Lohrey has won the $80,000 Prime Minister's Literary Award for her seventh novel, The Labyrinth — compounding a banner year in which she also won the $60,000 Miles Franklin Literary Award.
node.content:
["Tasmanian author Amanda Lohrey has won the $80,000 Prime Minister's Literary Award for her seventh novel, The Labyrinth \u2014 compounding a banner year in which she also won the $60,000 Miles Franklin Literary Award.", "In bestowing the award \u2014 one of the richest literary prizes in Australia \u2014 the judges praised Lohrey as \"a writer of uncompromising artistic purpose who is never content for the novel to be mere entertainment\".", "In The Labyrinth, a woman moves to a coastal town to be closer to her estranged and imprisoned son \u2014 and builds a labyrinth in her backyard, as a way of coping with her grief and uncertainty.", "", "
Garra Nalla \u2014 the coastal hamlet setting of The Labyrinth \u2014 was also the setting of Lohrey's 2009 novella Vertigo.(Supplied:\u00a0Text Publishing)
", "In a speech delivered by her agent Lyn Tranter, Lohrey lamented the diminished status of Australian literature in our universities.", "\"Australian literature has never been richer, or more diverse. So it was a great shock when our oldest university \u2014 [University of] Sydney \u2014 recently abolished its chair of Australian Literature. I look forward to the day when the university re-establishes an institution that any self-respecting nation should be proud to showcase,\" she said.", "More to follow.", "Fiction:", "Amanda Lohrey for The Labyrinth", "Non-fiction:", "Quentin Sprague for The Stranger Artist: Life at the Edge of Kimberley Painting", "Poetry:", "Stephen Edgar for The Strangest Place:\u00a0New and Selected Poems", "Australian history:", "Grace Karskens for People of the River: Lost Worlds of Early Australia", "Young adult literature:", "Cath Moore for Metal Fish, Falling Snow", "Children's literature (shared):", "Remy Lai for Fly on the Wall", "Meg McKinlay (writer) and Matt Ottley (illustrations) for How to Make a Bird"]
